newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: HIA says Australia rate cut factored in to outlook.
newsitem.headline: HIA says Australia rate cut factored in to outlook.

text.p: The Housing Industry Association of Australia said on Friday it had factored a potential interest rate cut into its latest housing start figures, which it said showed housing affordability at its highest point this decade.

"Housing affordability reached its highest point this decade in the March quarter of 1997, leading the Housing Industry Association to predict a 13 percent increase in housing starts this year, to 136,700, and a further 13 percent in 1998, to 154,100," the HIA said in a statement.

The statement was prepared before the Reserve Bank of Australia announced a cut of half a percent in official interest rates to 5.5 percent. "We fully expected (the RBA) to do this," HIA spokesman Kevin Randall said.
HIA policy director Christianna Cobbold said a big swing to multi-unit housing was another highlight of the association's latest quarterly building industry review.
Approvals for multi-unit dwellings rose 35 percent over the year to March 1997, compared to a rise of four percent for detached dwellings, Cobbold said in a statement.
Housing approvals for the quarter to March 1997 were equal to a rate of 139,000 dwellings a year, up 14 percent on the annual rate a year earlier, she Cobbold.
Renovation figures were up four percent in the December quarter of 1996 to an annual rate of A$2.46 billion.
"With interest rates down and economic growth and employment likely to pick up in the year ahead, renovation starts should continue to increase," Cobbold said.
Work on non-residential building was up six percent in 1996 to more than A$11.6 billion.

The HIA said it expects work in this sector to rise another five percent this year to about A$12.3 billion, with strong increases in New South Wales, Western Australia and the Australian Capital Territory likely to be partly offset by declines in Victoria and Tasmania.
